text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.17.3, Publishing - Tax Products Program.
1.17.3.2.3(3) - Added information on requirements for print vendors handling Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII).
1.17.3.5.7(1) - Updated to reﬂect the authority for the three primary procurement
All IRS employees, contractors, and vendors who design, publish, or distribute printed and/or material.

Taxpayers use these materials for return submissions, taxpayer education and assistance, and tax payments and withholdings. Each tax product the IRS creates results from new or revised legislation, regulations, rulings; court decisions; or suggestions from IRS employees or the public. Publishing is the ONLY internal organization with the authority to publish tax products to IRS.gov and the Core Repository of Published (CROPP). See IRM

) This section covers the publishing programs for IRS tax products that provide informational, promotional, and instructional materials to businesses and indi- viduals. Taxpayers use these materials for return submissions, taxpayer education and assistance, and tax payments and withholdings. Each tax product the IRS creates results from new or revised legislation, regulations, or rulings; court decisions; or suggestions from IRS employees or the taxpaying public. Publishing is the ONLY internal organization with the authority to publish tax products to IRS.gov and the Core Repository of Published (CROPP). See IRM
, Electronic Availability via the Core Repository of Published Products (CROPP), and to procure printed tax products refer to IRM
, Authorities of Government Publishing, Printing, and Duplicating.

The IRS produces tax products in the following publishing programs: • Tax Forms and Instructions • Taxpayer Information Publications (TIPS) • Tax Payment Voucher Mail Outs The IRS produces tax forms and instructions to assist the public with standing and submitting tax information. All taxpayers use tax forms tax returns. The forms usually include the instructions for general however, instructions are occasionally furnished separately. series), Employers (Form

and series), and other support and supplemental forms and instructions. and instructions are available in print and/or electronic formats. Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Numbers - All tax forms valid OMB number before being published or printed. For a list of numbers assigned to forms, visit default.aspx. The TIPS program provides taxpayers with detailed information on that assist with preparation of their tax returns. TIPS are designed to ment forms and instructions by answering typical tax questions and helpful examples for a particular topic. We provide TIPS in print or formats. An example of TIPS is Pub
, Farmer’s Tax Guide. The IRS mails Package

-ES/V (Payment Vouchers), which estimated tax payment vouchers preprinted with the taxpayer’s name, and social security number (SSN), using Pre-sorted First Class Mail, taxpayers who: • E-ﬁle • File using computer program (such as Turbo Tax) • File their returns using a preparer • File paper returns The taxpayer’s SSN is embedded in the scan line of the Form

File using computer program (such as Turbo Tax) File their returns using a preparer File paper returns

The taxpayer’s SSN is embedded in the scan line of the Form 1040-V and Form 1040-ES (Optical Character Recognition) payment vouchers. The scan line identiﬁes the taxpayer and enables efficient processing of payments. The payment vouchers contain a PDF 417 2-D encrypted barcode with random
scan-line information. The IRS uses these vouchers to collect quarterly tax payments and any balances due for the current year from taxpayers. (
) The IRS mails Package

-ES (Payment Vouchers), which includes estimated tax payment vouchers for Estates and Trusts preprinted with the payer’s name, address and Employee Identiﬁcation Number (EIN), using sorted First Class Mail, to taxpayers who: • E-ﬁle • File using computer program (such as Turbo Tax) • File their returns using a preparer • File paper returns The Employee Identiﬁcation Number (EIN) is embedded in the scan line of Form
-ES (OCR) payment vouchers. The scan line identiﬁes the and enables efficient processing of payments. The payment vouchers a PDF
-D encrypted barcode with random scan-line information. The uses these vouchers to collect quarterly tax payments and any balances for the year for an estate or trust. (

) The Publishing Specialists also work closely with Contractor Security ment (CSM) and the Human Capital Office (HCO) to ensure that the print contractors have the necessary clearances to work with Personally Information (PII) and Sensitive but Unclassiﬁed Information (SBU). This process involves ﬁngerprinting, background checks, credit checks, selective service enrollment and tax compliancy. Only after they receive clearance contractor work on IRS work involving PII. (
) The Publishing Specialist must ensure that each print contractor is up to with their annual mandatory brieﬁngs and that their training is recorded in terprise Learning Management System (ELMS). (
) Customers can obtain IRS tax products and services in the following ways: • Electronically, e.g., via IRS website and IRWeb; • By placing an order; or • By Walk-In at an IRS-approved location. (

) IRS tax products are accessible via the Internet from the IRS website at irs.gov. In addition, several software products are available from retail that generate IRS-acceptable versions of tax forms and instructions. Pub General Rules and Speciﬁcations for Substitute Forms and Schedules, pro- vides general guidelines on the acceptability of these products. (

) IRS e-ﬁle enables taxpayers and tax professionals to ﬁle tax returns cally. Publishing prints the products that are maintained in the e-ﬁle E-ﬁle is the brand name of the electronic ﬁling method established by the
scan-line information. The IRS uses these vouchers to collect quarterly tax payments and any balances due for the current year from taxpayers.

-ES (Payment Vouchers), which includes estimated tax payment vouchers for Estates and Trusts preprinted with the tax- payer’s name, address and Employee Identiﬁcation Number (EIN), using Pre- sorted First Class Mail, to taxpayers who:
uses these vouchers to collect quarterly tax payments and any balances due for the year for an estate or trust. The Publishing Specialists also work closely with Contractor Security Manage

ment (CSM) and the Human Capital Office (HCO) to ensure that the print contractors have the necessary clearances to work with Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII) and Sensitive but Unclassiﬁed Information (SBU). This process involves ﬁngerprinting, background checks, credit checks, selective service enrollment and tax compliancy. Only after they receive clearance can a contractor work on IRS work involving PII.

The CROPP is a publishing management system that collects, stores, manages, and delivers published products for use in electronic publishing ap- plications. Access to this system is only available to IRS employees.

) Tax products in these programs are designed to help taxpayers understand laws and IRS procedures, and to obtain assistance with tax return Availability for The products supplement IRS services such as Volunteer Income Tax and tance (VITA), Tax Counseling for the Elderly (TCE), and Community Tax Education. See http://publish.no.irs.gov/pubsys/taxpyred/taxpyred.html details on Understanding Taxes Program for Students. For details on products related to the Small Business Program, see IRM IRM
, Business Tax Products Distribution (SBTPD) Program, or ﬁnd more at http://publish.no.irs.gov/distsys/smallbus/sbrc.html. (

) The Taxpayer Assistance Center (TAC) Program is designed to supply IRS TAC Walk-In offices with tax forms, instructions, and publications for Availability via tion to the public. Information on the program is available under Services Assistance the publish.no.irs.gov website or at http://publish.no.irs.gov/distsys/pod/pod. (TAC) Program html. (

) The VITA Program uses trained volunteers to prepare basic tax returns for income taxpayers in both urban and rural locations, persons with Availability via non-English speaking persons, taxpayers with Limited English Proﬁciency, Income Tax elderly taxpayers, and Native Americans. See (VITA) vita/vita.html for more details. (
) The Tax Counseling for the Elderly (TCE) Program offers FREE tax help to dividuals who are aged
or older. The Revenue Act of

authorizes Availability via cooperative agreement by providing grants to private or non-governmental for the public non-proﬁt agencies and organizations (grant recipients) to assist (TCE) Program taxpayers with preparing their federal income tax returns. (
) All TCE sites must have one physical or electronic copy of the following reference materials available for use by volunteer return preparers and reviewers:
The Tax Counseling for the Elderly (TCE) Program offers FREE tax help to in- dividuals who are aged
or older. The Revenue Act of

authorizes this cooperative agreement by providing grants to private or non-governmental public non-proﬁt agencies and organizations (grant recipients) to assist elderly taxpayers with preparing their federal income tax returns.
• Pub
, VITA/TCE Volunteer Resource Guide • Pub
, Your Federal Income Tax (For Individuals) • Volunteer Tax Alerts – must be available at the site within ﬁve (
) of Stakeholder Partnerships, Education and Communication (SPEC) issuance In addition, all grant recipients must ﬁll out a Form
-C, Intake/Interview and Quality Review Sheet. (
) Tax return preparation assistance is provided to elderly taxpayers during the usual period for ﬁling federal income tax returns, which is from January
to April
each year. However, the program activities required to ensure that elderly taxpayers receive efficient and quality tax assistance can be year-round. (

) Libraries, post offices, and other entities volunteer as distribution outlet partners in the Tax Forms Outlet Program, formerly known as the Banks, Availability via Offices, and Libraries (BPOL) Program. The outlets order printed IRS tax Outlet products offered through the TFOP and make these printed tax products (TFOP) available to their respective patrons free of charge. Participants in the provide various tax products that are made available to them. (
) Some partner outlets order/receive Pub
, Reproducible Copies of Tax Forms and Instructions, from which patrons may photocopy tax charge may apply. (
) TFOP outlet partners use a program customized PDF Form
, Order for Tax Forms Outlet Program (TFOP) Partners, posted at cat
cgi?request=CAT
&catnum=
, to place their order by email to a designated email mailbox. (
) See http://publish.no.irs.gov/distsys/bpol/tfop.html for details on the TFOP program. (

) The International Program (formerly Embassy Program) provides U.S. embassies, consulates, and military bases around the world with bulk tax Availability via products for redistribution. This program is designed to make tax-ﬁling materials available to many U.S. taxpayers traveling or stationed abroad. (

) Taxpayers may also use paid tax return preparers to complete tax returns by paper or electronically. These preparers are required to use, order and Availability via maintain approved IRS forms and e-ﬁle systems. New regulations require all Return Preparers paid tax return preparers to have a preparer tax identiﬁcation number This includes enrolled agents, registered tax return preparers, certiﬁed public accountants (CPAs), or attorneys – all of whom have unlimited rights to work with tax returns. The IRS is also phasing in a new test requirement to make sure those who are not an enrolled agent, a CPA, or an attorney have met minimal competency requirements. Taxpayers are legally responsible for is on their tax return even if it is prepared by someone else.

1.17.3.3.6.4 (10-14-2015) Walk-in Availability via Tax Forms Outlet Program (TFOP)
(10-14-2015) Walk-in Availability via the International Program
Taxpayers may also use paid tax return preparers to complete tax returns by paper or electronically. These preparers are required to use, order and maintain approved IRS forms and e

ﬁle systems. New regulations require all paid tax return preparers to have a preparer tax identiﬁcation number (PTIN). This includes enrolled agents, registered tax return preparers, certiﬁed public accountants (CPAs), or attorneys – all of whom have unlimited rights to work with tax returns. The IRS is also phasing in a new test requirement to make sure those who are not an enrolled agent, a CPA, or an attorney have met minimal competency requirements. Taxpayers are legally responsible for what is on their tax return even if it is prepared by someone else.

Taxpayers may also use paid tax return preparers to complete tax returns by paper or electronically. These preparers are required to use, order and maintain approved IRS forms and e-ﬁle systems. New regulations require all paid tax return preparers to have a preparer tax identiﬁcation number (PTIN). This includes enrolled agents, registered tax return preparers, certiﬁed public accountants (CPAs), or attorneys – all of whom have unlimited rights to work with tax returns. The IRS is also phasing in a new test requirement to make sure those who are not an enrolled agent, a CPA, or an attorney have met minimal competency requirements. Taxpayers are legally responsible for
Program

) Although every functional area of the IRS is involved in the development issuance of tax forms program material, the Director, Media & Publications responsible for the overall development, printing, and distribution of tax products in a timely, cost-efficient manner. within (

) TF&P develops and revises tax products in accordance with legislation enacted by Congress and ensures that the products are technically understandable, and as easy to use as possible so taxpayers can fulﬁll their tax ﬁlling and payment obligations. TF&P then submits the content to ing to be formatted and published. Publishing partners with TF&P to ensure that products are produced correctly and on time. (
) TF&P maintains product development and legislative data in appropriate product databases, and submits requests to Publishing to change the status products and their revisions as required. (

) Publishing plans, designs, prints, and distributes all official IRS published products in print or electronic formats for use by the public to comply with ﬁling and payment requirements and obligations or for use within the IRS tax administration. This encompasses the integrated design, speciﬁcations writing, production planning, acquisition, and delivery/distribution required to provide the highest-quality products and services, using all print and electronic media and technology available. Publishing maintains data products and their revisions in appropriate M&P product databases to the availability of product revisions on www.irs.gov and in the Catalog at publish.no.irs.gov/catlg.html. (

) Distribution works closely with Publishing to coordinate with contractors on movement of products and with publishing specialists to determine and products to be printed. Both organizations cooperate to determine methods of printing and distribution would be the best value. See IRM
, Distribution, for more information on Distribution responsibilities. (

) The IRS stores printed products at the NDC. The NDC receives bulk shipments of printed tax products and redistributes them based on requests from IRS internal and external customers. The NDC is located in IL and is a branch within the Distribution division of M&P. See IRM
, National Distribution Center, for more information on the NDC programs and operations. (
) The steps for developing tax products are described in the tax products workﬂow. Document
, Getting Your Information Published at the IRS, also contains the workﬂow Publishing follows to produce tax and other IRS published products. (
) Customers use the Publishing Services Request (PSR) to initiate a product request. See IRM
, Importance of Standards and Submitting a ing Services Request, for more information on the PSR process.

TF&P develops and revises tax products in accordance with legislation enacted by Congress and ensures that the products are technically accurate, understandable, and as easy to use as possible so taxpayers can fulﬁll their tax ﬁlling and payment obligations. TF&P then submits the content to Publish- ing to be formatted and published. Publishing partners with TF&P to ensure that products are produced correctly and on time.

Customers use the Publishing Services Request (PSR) to initiate a product request. See IRM 1.17.9.5, Importance of Standards and Submitting a Publish- ing Services Request, for more information on the PSR process.

) Publishing provides the PSR electronic application for customers to request Publishing products and services. Customers initiate a PSR by going to the PSR homepage at http://caps-as.enterprise.irs.gov/psr/app. The PSR auto- mates the process of obtaining business and funding approvals, gathering product information, and initiating contact with Publishing. Once the submits the PSR, it is assigned to a publishing specialist for service. ers can also use a PSR to request any type of publishing service that previ- ously required a Form
,Publishing Services Request. No design, publishing, or distribution is done without a PSR. (

) After the PSR is approved, the clearance procedure begins by having a tax law specialist review the tax product for clarity and accuracy. During the clearance procedure, Publishing, TF&P, and the Tax Products Coordinating Committee prepare, review, and revise drafts of tax products. Once content ﬁnalized, TF&P selects the ″release to Publishing OK to print″ option in the Composition Process Management system, sending notiﬁcation to the Elec- tronic Composition section. (

) The Electronic Composition Section obtains or creates a ﬁnal reproducible Portable Document Format (PDF) ﬁle of each tax product and performs a quality review of ﬁllable PDFs of tax forms. The section creates and Text Section

-compliant quality reviews of PDFs for tax products and forwards them to the Alternative Media Center (AMC). Composition also creates native electronic versions of publications and instructions for Section
compliance (e.g., an HTML version), and for use on mobile devices (e.g., an

ook version). Composition posts PDFs and other related ﬁles for all in alternative formats to the Core Repository of Published Products and stages ﬁles for posting to www.irs.gov for upload via the Electronic Tax Forms Distribution (ETFD) application. Stakeholders (publishing specialists distribution analysts) receive notiﬁcation when OK-to-Print ﬁles are available printing and posting. (

) Once Electronic Composition provides an OK-to-Print ﬁle, the publishing cialist updates and issues the product information as an Electronic Status Notice (ESN). ESN is software that tracks and maintains a catalog of published by the IRS. See IRM

, Electronic Status Notice (ESN), more information about ESN. Issuing is the ﬁnal step in updating a product’s information. This step communicates with the catalog page on the website, which houses all the products the IRS publishes, located at http:// publish.no.irs.gov/catlg.html, and makes the products available for all IRS ployees to see. The catalog page reﬂects any changes made to the information in ESN. (
) Form
, Distribution List, also includes the product and vendor Publishing specialists should email the distribution analyst to request a Form
after issuing the product in ESN. Form
is only available electroni- cally and can only be accessed by publishing specialists from the M&P Intranet site.

Once Electronic Composition provides an OK-to-Print ﬁle, the publishing spe- cialist updates and issues the product information as an Electronic Status Notice (ESN). ESN is software that tracks and maintains a catalog of products published by the IRS. See IRM

, Electronic Status Notice (ESN), for more information about ESN. Issuing is the ﬁnal step in updating a product’s information. This step communicates with the catalog page on the Publishing website, which houses all the products the IRS publishes, located at http:// publish.no.irs.gov/catlg.html, and makes the products available for all IRS em- ployees to see. The catalog page reﬂects any changes made to the product’s information in ESN.
Form
, Distribution List, also includes the product and vendor information. Publishing specialists should email the distribution analyst to request a Form
after issuing the product in ESN. Form
is only available electroni- cally and can only be accessed by publishing specialists from the M&P Page
Intranet site.

) There are three primary procurement vehicles established by the Publishing Office (GPO) for the production of tax products. Only publishing specialists are authorized to use these procurement vehicles. Publishing spe- cialists initiate the procurement and print production of IRS published using the following forms: a. GPO Form

, Print Order - Purpose: Authorizes standardized work be performed on a term contract. Use: This form is completed by the questing agency or by the Government Publishing Office (GPO) procurement office when jobs are converted from a requisition to a print order to be placed on a term contract. No bid is required. b. GPO Form

, Simpliﬁed Purchase Agreement (SPA) Work Order - Purpose: Authorizes a contractor to manufacture and ship products to a GPO customer. Use: This form allows a GPO customer to order directly from a contractor. Depending on the cost, a bid from multiple contractors may be required. c. Standard Form
, Printing and Binding Requisition - Purpose: The only authorized format for submission of high-cost or non-standardized and binding requirements from government agencies. (

) The Tax Form Printing Program is one of the primary ways for the IRS to municate the tax law to the general public. Therefore, quality is important during all phases of preparation and production. Quality, in terms of typogra- phy, design, format, readability, usability, and product printability, must be a prime part of all review and decision-making steps. (

) Prior to actual printing production, Publishing exercises quality control a planning and review process that ensures: a. The item is properly cleared, authorized, and identiﬁed through form numbering, catalog numbering, etc.; b. The selected styles and sizes of type adhere to accepted tax forms standards; c. The format and printed product speciﬁcations will produce the most effective and economical product to fulﬁll the need; d. Adequate scheduling and planning time has been allowed, where possible, to minimize the possibility of error; e. All proofs and copy are reviewed for accuracy; f. The ﬁnal reproduction proofs have consistent tonal density, high and sharp/clear images; g. All printing instructions are precise, clearly understandable, and consis- tent with printing trade customs; and Internal Revenue Manual
GPO Form

, Print Order - Purpose: Authorizes standardized work be performed on a term contract. Use: This form is completed by the questing agency or by the Government Publishing Office (GPO) procurement office when jobs are converted from a requisition to a print order to be placed on a term contract. No bid is required. GPO Form

, Simpliﬁed Purchase Agreement (SPA) Work Order - Purpose: Authorizes a contractor to manufacture and ship products to a GPO customer. Use: This form allows a GPO customer to order directly from a contractor. Depending on the cost, a bid from multiple contractors may be required. Standard Form
, Printing and Binding Requisition - Purpose: The only authorized format for submission of high-cost or non-standardized and binding requirements from government agencies.

The item is properly cleared, authorized, and identiﬁed through form numbering, catalog numbering, etc.; The selected styles and sizes of type adhere to accepted tax forms standards; The format and printed product speciﬁcations will produce the most effective and economical product to fulﬁll the need; Adequate scheduling and planning time has been allowed, where possible, to minimize the possibility of error; All proofs and copy are reviewed for accuracy; The ﬁnal reproduction proofs have consistent tonal density, high and sharp/clear images; All printing instructions are precise, clearly understandable, and tent with printing trade customs; and

During the production of IRS products, Publishing may conduct onsite press sheet inspection visits to control, as much as possible, the quality of the ﬁnal product. Quality, from a program management standpoint, also extends beyond the tangible parameters of the published product. Publishing schedules and nates all elements required to ensure a successful procurement including: • Planning and scheduling to meet critical deadlines; • Coordinating and communicating actual requirements among a of sources; • Evaluating the importance of user needs and translating these into positive actions; • Providing guidance and advice on the impact of any program • Evaluating procedures, methods, and costs on a continuing basis; • Determining alternatives necessary to ensure mission fulﬁllment; and • Instituting systems for monitoring and controlling all aspects of the curement. To ensure an adequate level of quality, Publishing conducts a quality assurance review that may include Publishing onsite press sheet During or after an onsite press sheet inspection, Publishing personnel will: • Conduct a thorough quality assurance inspection of each selected tax item, using Form

, Quality Assurance Inspection Report, as a guide. • Notify the Government Publishing Office (GPO) by email or telephone any situation that requires immediate corrective action. Only the GPO, as the official contracting officer, is authorized to make any changes to the printing contracts. M&P Publishing personnel who perform press sheet inspections are not authorized to change printing contracts.
